Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Thumb and Index Finger Techniques for Laryngeal Mask Airway Insertion

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to Group I (Index Finger) or Group T (Thumb Insertion), with 20 patients in each group.

Participants.evidence: Forty patients, aged 18-60 years, classified as American Society of Anesthesiologists grade I and II, were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to Group I (Index Finger) or Group T (Thumb Insertion)

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the thumb insertion technique with the conventional index finger technique for inserting the silicone laryngeal mask airway (LMA) Classicâ„¢ in patients undergoing elective surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was ease of insertion, measured immediately after insertion.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using sealed numbered envelopes, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on all randomised participants, adhering to an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both groups demonstrated comparable results in terms of ease of insertion, fiberoptic view scores, cuff pressures, and laryngopharyngeal morbidity.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
